subject: Education
title: The Myth of Multitasking: Your Brain Can't Do It
description: A quick win: understand The Myth of Multitasking: Your Brain Can't Do It.

hook.text: You're not multitasking. You're rapidly switching between tasks, losing 40% of your productivity with each switch.

buildup.text: The brain cannot process two cognitive tasks simultaneously. What feels like multitasking is actually task-switching.

discovery.text: Each switch costs 'attention residue' ‚Äî part of your brain stays stuck on the previous task for up to 15 minutes.

twist.text: Students who text during lectures score 14% lower on exams ‚Äî even when they think they're keeping up perfectly.

climax.text: Multitasking doesn't save time ‚Äî it destroys depth. Deep learning requires sustained, uninterrupted attention.

punchline.text: Multitasking is doing two things badly while believing you're doing both well.

quiz.question: What actually happens when people 'multitask'?
options: They rapidly switch between tasks, losing productivity with each switch
